page.title: 03LANDSCAPE/BUILDING/CHIGNALS
page.content: Mashbury and the Chignals are mainly agricultural areas. Most of the buildings are farm houses and many of the remaining residences are occupied by the elderly. The houses that stand in this area are fairly old, e.g. Mashbury Hall and a number of them display the local art of pargeting. Most of the area is approximately 77 metres above sea level and gently undulating. The majority of the land is used for growing crops, with a few copses. There are a number of small reservoirs in the area. The soil comprises of a chalky boulder clay with belts of gravel running through it, which provides good drianage for crop growing. The gravel is also excavated for commercial use.
